captions.text:
Oh, Resident Evil 7, you&#39;ve made me the happiest
game critic in the world.
But what furrows your brow, my love?

Oh I was just thinking about when I was Resident
Evil 2.

Well why the fuck were you thinking about
that?
You&#39;ve moved on, Resident Evil.
You&#39;re a good game now.

About genuinely creepy things happening to
real characters but with an ironic self-awareness
that gives you that crucial edge.

Yeah, but people seemed to like Resident Evil
2, I think I should remake it.

Oh you poor beautiful deluded video game box
art on legs.

You do that and you&#39;ll get half the audience
complaining about its lack of modern sensibilities

and the other half complaining that it&#39;s not
like how they remember it.
You don&#39;t need them, you&#39;ve got me now.
Don&#39;t throw it all away for nostalgia&#39;s sake.

You&#39;re romanticising the past and overlooking
the negatives from those days.

The pathetic plots, the prodigious Playstation
pixels, that weird zombie eating flesh sound

effect that sounded like someone repeatedly
stomping on a juice box.

You do this and you&#39;ll be sliding back onto
that dreadful path that led us to Resident

Evil 6, the game best summarised by replacing
the I in SIX with a U. Fine, run to your remake

friends, but I&#39;m gonna give it a damn good
kick in the sensibilities.

So I was already iffy on the RE2Make &#39;cos
the very idea is what we call a &quot;mouthful

of dinner plate&quot; because it makes me do this:
&quot;Eeeeeehhhhhhh.&quot;

And then reviews started coming in and virtually
all of them praise it for being &quot;true to the

original&quot; and that made the dinner plate double
in size.
&quot;EEEEEEEEHHHHHH.&quot;
Who gives a fuck if it&#39;s &quot;true to the original?&quot;
I&#39;ll tell you who: cunts.

Small-trousered nostalgianauts who burrow
ever deeper into their comfort zones at the
slightest threat of challenging new idea.

Then I played through Resident Evil 2, both
bits of it, and I can state with resounding
certainty that it&#39;s &quot;alright&quot;.

This is the part where all the cockthroats
swoop down on the comments like flies to a

dead dog and go &quot;Ooh an alright from Yahtzee
is high praise anywhere else, buzz buzz.&quot;

Eat that dead dog&#39;s last panicky burst of
diarrhoetic shit, cockthroats.

Resident Evil at its best is something I&#39;ve
found electrifying and this conflux of old

ideas and slightly less old but still old
ideas is barely two licks of a nine volt.

The problem might have been that the plot
is still trying to build suspense about its

twists and reveals despite the fact that we
already know everything that happens.

I was playing the fourth sequel to this game
like three years ago, it&#39;s like watching a

fucking nativity play at this point, except
without the slim hope that someone might piss

themselves and cry, this not being Metal Gear
Solid.

Raccoon City has fallen to the zombies in
such a way that no one else in the country
noticed.

Only, like, two people have tried to enter
the city since the outbreak started, I&#39;m guessing
it&#39;s not exactly a tourism economy.

The two being, Leon Kennedy, a rookie policeman
who looks and speaks like a grown up member

of Hanson struggling to find work in later
life, and Claire Redfield, sister of former

protagonist Chris, who felt the best way to
get back in touch would be to show up in person

at his workplace rather than, say, a Facebook
nudge.

The intro really emphasises the increase of
scope from zombie infested mansion to zombie

infested city as the camera pulls back to
reveal a dense network of chaotic streets

that form together into the Resident Evil
2 logo.
Very nicely done.

Just a shame that the subsequent game takes
place almost entirely in a single building.

Alright, fine, there&#39;s a secret laboratory
as well.
But come on.

Every Resident Evil game has one of those,
if you&#39;re gonna count that as a location you
might as well count the fucking options menu.

But credit where it&#39;s due, Verydense Enid
2 is a very solidly designed game.

It certainly makes the most of its limited
space with its multiple story paths running

through its labyrinth of hallways that you
must explore and unpick like a mess of tangled
Christmas lights.

The game balances the survival part of survival
horror perfectly, ensuring that you&#39;re forever

low on stuff but always have just enough to
squeak by, it&#39;s as much about strategy as

action as you plan your next route and decide
if it&#39;s worth expending the ammo to down every

monster for the count or just pop &#39;em in the
face and run as you would casually whip a

passing exposed buttock as you sprint through
the men&#39;s locker room with a wet towel.

But that doesn&#39;t mean the action&#39;s any slouch;
the now-inevitable RE4-style combat is as

solid as ever, the guns have the right kick
and the gore effects are just delightful.
What&#39;s that on your face, Mr. Zombie?
BLAM.
Oh, it&#39;s the skirting board.

What I don&#39;t like so much is the big indestructible
neckbeard in a trenchcoat and fedora who pursues

you relentlessly from room to room because
you made the mistake of admitting that you

liked an anime once and now he won&#39;t leave
you alone until he&#39;s shown you his entire
Blu-Ray collection.

I get that once we&#39;ve gone over the hallways
enough times to start getting familiar we

need something to keep us unnerved and he
certainly does that as his massive Pocky-inflated

bulk stomps toward you making all the walls
shake, but over time he becomes more annoying

than scary, like those Silent Hill 4 ghosts
that keep nibbling your bum and playing their

stereos too loud while you&#39;re trying to get
the exploration and puzzle solving done.

Eventually you realise that his mum told him
he can&#39;t follow you into certain rooms, so

I&#39;d duck into a safe room and listen to his
thundering footsteps echo through the building

not having a chuffin&#39; clue where the fucker
actually is, and then I&#39;ll pop my head out
and oh!

He&#39;s right outside boring a Licker to death
with his opinions on Sword Art Online 2, back
in the saferoom.

This isn&#39;t creepy survival horror, this is
a mailman trying to negotiate with an angry
dog in a front yard.

Come to think of it, all the &#39;boss encounters&#39;
were a bit yawnsome.

I&#39;m sure having to navigate around a giant
muscle man in a small room trying to peck

at their weak spots while staying out of range
of their claw swipes was the height of creativity

back in the Playstation middle ages when expectations
were even lower than the fucking pixel resolution

but Resident Evil has come up with, like,
97,000 more creative set pieces since then.
And put them all in Resident Evil 4.

Oh but it&#39;s being true to the original, Yahtz
- LICK MY GRITTY PRITT STICK, viewer.

I did enjoy my time with RE2Make but the enthusiasm
I can summon is limited largely because of

its truth to the original, with all its banal
bubo-bursting boss fights and charisma vacuum

characters and frankly I think it&#39;s a step
back after RE7.

There&#39;s a bit early on where Leon and Claire
reunite either side of a fence and it&#39;s like

watching two awkward teenage schoolfriends
running into each other at the county fair.
&quot;Hey!&quot;
&quot;Hey.
Whatcha doing?&quot;
&quot;Not much.
You look pretty.&quot;
&quot;Thanks.
That zombie&#39;s gonna kill you.&quot;
&quot;I know, right?
They&#39;re sooo annoying.&quot;

Ethan Winters could out-personality either
of them and he was just a pair of wrists that
occasionally swore.

It&#39;s a classic example of what was once termed
a Second Order Idiot Plot, or situation that

could only exist if every character is an
idiot.

Hey, I&#39;m going to ride my bike to another
city to see if my brother is at the police
station.
Did you try phoning the police station?
Ehhhhhhhhhhhhhh.

Hey, I&#39;m going to make a virus that transforms
people into gigantic super strong monsters
for military applications.

How would that be more efficient than just
dropping a big bomb?
Ehhhhhhhhhhh.

And anyway, wouldn&#39;t it violate the square
cube law?
Ehhhhhhhhhhh...
Oh, never mind.
Just spit out the dinner plate.
